availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Joseph Rogers Underwood (Warren County, Kentucky, attorney, judge, and politician)

body.p: Warren County, Kentucky, attorney, judge, and politician. Goochland County, Virginia, native. Son of John Underwood and Francis Rogers Underwood. Married to Elizabeth McCowes Trotter Underwood in Barren County, Kentucky, on March 26, 1817. Father of Eugene Underwood, Julia Underwood Cox, Eliza L. Underwood, and Jane Underwood. Married to Elizabeth Cox Underwood in Washington, D.C., on February 25, 1839. Father of John Underwood, Robert Underwood, Thomas Underwood, Edith Underwood, Elizabeth Underwood, and Josephine Underwood. Graduate of Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky, in 1811. Read law with Robert Wickliffe in Lexington in 1811. Served in the 13th Regiment of the Kentucky Militia as a lieutenant in the War of 1812 in 1813. Admitted to the bar in 1813. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Barren County from 1816 to 1819. Presidential elector from the Third Congressional District of Kentucky in 1824. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Warren County from 1825 to 1827. Unsuccessful Opposition candidate for Lieutenant Governor for the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1828. Resident of Warren County in 1830. Owned three enslaved persons in Warren County in 1830. Judge of the Kentucky Court of Appeals in Frankfort from 1828 to 1835. Resident of Warren County in 1840. Owned thirteen enslaved persons in Warren County in 1840. Member of the Whig party. Member of the United States House of Representatives from the Third Congressional District of Kentucky from 1835 to 1844. Presidential elector for the Whig party from the Third Congressional District of Kentucky in 1844. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Warren County from 1845 to 1847. Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1846. Member of the United States Senate from 1847 to 1853. Attorney in Warren County in 1850. Farmer in Warren County in 1850. Owned five enslaved persons in Warren County in 1850. Attorney in Warren County in 1860. Owned seven enslaved persons in Warren County in 1860. Member of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky from Warren County from 1860 to 1863. Delegate to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, Illinois, in 1864. Attorney in Warren County, Kentucky, in 1865.
